title: Can I strip BOTH my second mortgage AND HOA liens in a BK 13 in California?
question: I am trying to find the latest rulings on lien and debt stripping in BK 13. The identical condo next door just sold for 139K. My first is 157K, and my second is 155K which i have not paid in 2 years. I did not pay my HOA for 2 years and they placed a lien on my condo for $8K. I entered a repayment agreemnent for the past due HOA and pay $300 monthly plus current HOA dues of. $339. HELP! Is this a good time to file BK13? I have a new job after being unemployed for 2 years. I make 70K per year, half my former salary. I dont want to be saddled with debt again. I also owe $80K on my credit cards which I stopped paying 2 years ago. No one has sued me yet. What is your opinion? Thanks so much, I plan on hiring a lawyer.
answers:
Assuming the FMV of the property is < 1st lien, YES you will be able to strip both the 2nd and the HOA lien. Some HOAs have contested 506 motions based on the theory that they are covenants that run with the land but almost all judges in CA have rejected this notion.

Here's a recent opinion fr Judge Smith in Santa Ana addressing whether HOA liens can be treated as unsecured via a 506 motion:

"The Association offers no legal authority supporting its position that an HOA lien should be treated any differently from other liens for purposes of Sec. 506.
The court finds the BAP's decision in Foster unavailaing as 1) it is interpreting Washington state law and 2) it concerns the applicability of the discharge provisions of 1328(a) to postpetition dues/assessments,
Importantly, California law does not treat HOA liens as "superliens." See, e.g.,Thaler v. Household Finance Corporation, 80 Cal.App.4th 1093, 1103 (2000) (rejecting the HOA's argument that a second trust deed recorded prior to recordation of its assessment subordinate, the Court referenced the following quote from Starr & Miller: "The burden on the . . . association is no different from the burden imposed on any creditor. Every creditor suffers the risk that a debtor may defeat collection of the obligation by over-encumbering his asset."); Diamond Heights Village Ass'n, Inc. v. Financial Freedom Senior Funding Corp.
196 Cal.App.4th 290, 303 ( “The debt is only a personal obligation of the owner, however, until the community association records a ‘notice of delinquent assessment’ against the owner's interest in the development. Recording this notice creates a lien and gives the association a security interest in the lot or unit against which the assessment was imposed.” (Sproul & Rosenberry, Advising Cal. Common Interest Communities
(Cont.Ed.Bar 2003) § 5.36, p. 328 [hereafter, Common Interest Communities]; see Civ.Code, § 1367, subd. (d).) The lien dates from the time the lien is **681 properly recorded. ( Thaler v. Household Finance Corp. (2000) 80 Cal.App.4th 1093, 1100–1102, 95 Cal.Rptr.2d 779.) “California follows the ‘first in time, first in right’ system of lien priorities.” Condominium assessment liens follow this same system."); andMountain Home Properties v. Pine Mountain Lake Assn. (1982) 135 Cal.App.3d 959, 968("covenants running with the land, including those contained in CC & R's, are to be strictly construed].)
The Association's lien securing the prepetition obligations is completely underwater and, therefore, may be stripped."

In most places, HOA liens are considered "statutory liens" & like tax liens, have priority even against your first mortgage, so it is doubtful a Chapter 13 can remove them, although you could propose a plan to repay this liens off at a reduced rate of interest.

For more information about lienstripping, see my videos at www.lienstripping.com . Hope this perspective helps!

You are a very good candidate for consideration for a chapter 13 bankruptcy. If your Condo is comparable to the one next door and would be appraised for less than your first mortgage then you will be able to strip off your second mortgage without much trouble. As for the HOA dues as you will be keeping your condo you will have to pay the arrears in your chapter 13 plan. You attorney will be also able to get this lien removed. Without knowing more about your circumstances it is difficult for one to say whether this is a good time for you to file. I can only suggest that you meet with an attorney to discuss these issues.

Schedule a consultation with an experienced chapter 13 attorney. They can go through the process and the anticipated results with you. Chapter 13 would likely allow you to strip off the second lien. Since I'm not licensed in CA I can't speak to how the HOA lien would be treated in a chapter 13 - that varies state to state.
